values.Professor#1: Correct!, Males recorded “no longer interested as to why they stopped 28.7% and females recorded that as their second highest reason.

$CEIdle|$POS0|$BGPovertyBackground|$BGMPoverty_BGM|Alright. Since you've chosen this level, you will experience this and answer my questions through the mindset of one of my favorite memoram, Elijah.

values.Professor#4: For this topic, we will be using the memoram we obtained when Elijah signed up for one of our programs.
values.Professor#5: I have to say he was one of the more pleasant interviewees I have had the pleasure to do this program with, unlike yourself.
values.Professor#6: And therefore for my sake, I will be making this a third person memoram experience, just so you can't ruin this for me.
values.Player#2: How fair. You absolute coward. If you are going to trap me, at least let me have some way to retaliate at you.
values.Professor#7: In your dreams. Now let's begin, shall we?
values.Narrator#1: *Professor snaps their fingers and Elijah seems to come to life and starts animating*
values.Professor#8: Hello there. Elijah, correct? How are you doing? And what can I do for you today?
values.Elijah#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|Hello there sir! I am doing absolutely fantastic. It is such an honor to meet you.
values.Elijah#2: Since you asked, I will just go straight to the point then.
values.Elijah#3: I have been thinking about volunteering for support work to further develop my resume and grow my experience as a member of society,...
values.Elijah#4: …but I am currently struggling to search up relevant resources to develop my views on the reality of poverty within Australia.
values.Narrator#2: *winks at Player, and you roll your eyes*
values.Professor#11: Now since you got straight to the point that you need more information on the current situation of poverty within Australia.
values.Professor#12: Let's take a step back and observe the meaning of poverty. Can you tell me what would be some indicators of poverty?

values.Elijah#1: From my observation, all of the answers seem to be indicators of poverty.
values.Elijah#2: Lacking money in a capitalist world is a very big indicator.
values.Elijah#3: Having limited to no access to food and clean water is also a big indicator.
values.Elijah#4: And a lack of shelter in our day and age can prove to be very problematic.
values.Professor#1: Absolutely correct, Elijah. Those are extremely good answers you've provided.
values.Professor#2: However, income is definitely the best numerical indicator for poverty as most definitions of poverty are mostly based on income.

values.Professor#1: Yikes!
Now comes another question, this is a graph that's obtained from careful observations from my colleague.
values.Professor#2: From this graph, can you tell me the global percentage of people that are making less than $5.49 per day?

values.Elijah#1: That is absolutely terrible…… 37.1% of people globally are making less than $5 per day?!
values.Elijah#2: Living in Australia, I would've never heard of that, I can't even imagine what that would feel like.
values.Professor#1: That's okay Elijah, you don't have to panic just yet.
values.Professor#2: I know it can feel very disheartening but that's what I am here for, are you feeling okay?
values.Elijah#3: I feel okay to proceed, I just feel a bit sad to hear that people can still earn less than what they deserve.
values.Player#1: Well it is quite saddening to hear that.
values.Player#2: But what's even more disheartening is that I am stuck here with an annoying know-it-all and a crybaby.
values.Narrator#1: *Professor stares at Player briefly and looks back at Elijah*
values.Professor#3: That's okay, Elijah. It means you have basic sympathy.

values.Professor#1: Incorrect! Yikes.
Now I will say that sometimes the percentage does not represent the actual poverty rate.
values.Professor#2: Let's try and understand that better shall we?
values.Professor#3: Now here is some dud data for you to practice on.

values.Professor#1: Incredible calculation and observational skill Elijah!
values.Professor#2: The reason why there is a big difference between the mean and median is because of the extreme variables within the dataset.

values.Elijah#1: Oh! That is so interesting. Can I-

values.Player#3: So how is learning any of these yip-yaps about statistics supposed to help him?
values.Professor#1: Well, if you have simply allowed the memoram to play through,...
values.Professor#2: …you would've gotten to know how Elijah will gain an understanding of how poverty is in Australia.
values.Professor#3: But unfortunately, you just rudely interrupted our conversation and just paused the memoram.
values.Player#4: Well sorry for just wanting to gain some understanding and find relevance in these questions I guess.
values.Elijah#2: $CEIdle|$POS1|Can I then just choose the most appropriate measurement according to what's required here?
values.Professor#5: Now think about this, if you are trying to carry out a study on the poverty rate in Australia with the data of everyone's income, which measurement should we look at? The mean or the median?

values.Elijah#1: Oh! That makes so much more sense.
values.Elijah#2: Since our datasets will be based on income, it's normal to have some extremely low or high values,...
values.Elijah#3: …and therefore it will be much more appropriate to use median income as a reference to poverty.

values.Professor#1: Sorry, that's wrong!

values.Player#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|Wow. We got a smart cookie over here.
values.Player#2: Now if he only knew that I am the one answering the questions and not him.
values.Player#3: How surprised do you reckon he would be.

values.Professor#1: That's right. We might think that poverty shouldn't be a serious problem here in Australia.
values.Professor#2: But if we take a look at the study by ACOSS(Australian Council of Social Service) and UNSW on the poverty issue in Australia 2021.
values.Professor#3: The study is based on the global standard poverty measurement which is 50% of the median income.
values.Professor#4: Now let's think about it together. Which data should we be using as the measurement for poverty rate?

Incorrect! Yikes.
According to their studies and surveys.
values.Professor#2: ACOSS and UNSW were able to estimate that 3,239,000 people in Australia are under the poverty line.
values.Professor#3: The population in Australia is around 23,810,000 in 2018.
values.Professor#4: Can you now work out the poverty rate from these numbers?

values.Elijah#1: The poverty rate is 13.6%. That's still quite high.
values.Professor#1: You got it!
Yikes
The calculation of poverty rate is simply using the number of people below the poverty line divided by the total population.
values.Professor#2: Now go ahead and have a look at this plot of the trends in median household disposable incomes, before and after deducting housing costs.
values.Professor#3: Does this data suggest a positive relationship? What does this mean?

values.Elijah#2: The graph suggests a positive relationship, which means the poverty rate is increasing in Australia every year.
values.Professor#1: It is quite depressing just to look at the graph by itself, yes.
values.Professor#2: But this is exactly why volunteering work coming from young people like you can help make a difference.

values.Professor#1: Hopefully these statistics have helped you gain clarity in the current situation surrounding poverty in Australia.
values.Elijah#1: It has. Thank you so much for your help.
values.Elijah#2: When I first signed up for this program to try and gain more understanding on this subject matter…

values.Professor#2: Likewise Elijah.

values.Professor#3: Well, that makes one of you guys.
values.Professor#4: Now I will also be asking you the same question.
values.Professor#5: Have you also obtained more understanding around poverty now that you've gone through Elijah's memoram?
values.Player#2: If I say sure would you just let me out of here?

values.Professor#1: Hmm.
Sure.

values.Rebecca#1: Oh christ! Where am I? What's going on? This room is so white it's actually hurting my eyes.

values.Professor#7: Now if you don't mind, I-

values.Rebecca#4: Before that old sod tries to get through that door and ask me stupid questions again, let me think of a way to bust myself-

values.Rebecca#5: WHAT! How did you manage to sneak behind me with…
values.Professor#9: Let me remind you that you are currently within a memoram.
values.Professor#10: Which is a virtual reality where we allow certain users to play through the memory of another person.
values.Professor#11: So you can't really just get away from me, as I am part of the system itself.
values.Professor#12: Were you really that naive to think that you can scram away when you are still within our system?
values.Professor#13: We brought you here for a reason, and we won't be letting you go until you learn what you have to learn.
values.Rebecca#6: Oh man. You are so irritating.
values.Professor#14: The feelings are mutual on this one.
values.Professor#15: Now! Onto our first question. What do you think a key indicator of good health in a country is?

values.1: Although there are many indicators at our disposal, Life expectancy is very reliable.

values.Rebecca#1: According to whatever is inside her head, life expectancy is the most reliable indicator for that?

values.Professor#1: That's so wrong!
According to whatever is inside her head, life expectancy is the most reliable indicator for that?
values.Professor#2: Then tell me, what do you think plays a big role in living a long life in Australia?

values.3: Demand and need for health and welfare services and health system costs

values.Professor#1: Ah yes. Save the smart-mouthing for answering my questions, yeah?
values.Rebecca#2: Fine. But answer me this, does the wealth of an individual necessarily determine how long they will live for?

Well, let me answer that question with another question.

values.2: Those living in higher socioeconomic areas on average live shorter lives.

values.Professor#1: Alright. For this I will partially answer it for you.
